Farewell, my feeble harp! — now rest awhile—</br>Perchance for ever — ne'er again to ring!—</br>Unless (blest thought!) some sweet benignant smile</br>Of fav'ring Fortune shall "awake thy string,"</br>And to my pow'rless hand new spirit bring—</br>But grant it so — yet should thy judges frown,</br>And thy poor lays to dark oblivion fling—</br>Then thou, my harp, must lie for ever down,</br>And moulder on the sward, amid some forest brown.

And to the solemn sentence I shall bow</br>In silence meek, nor e'er shall I repine—</br>Unnumber'd lays must to oblivion go,</br>Of which the race to come shall hear no line!—</br>For not round every brow the lay shall twine;</br>Its wreath unfading only crowns the few,</br>Within whose favour'd breasts the fire divine</br>Burns strong, and glows with warmth for ever new;</br>And when their bones are dust, Fame does with their shades pursue.—

Whate'er thy doom — lov'd harp!  I not regret</br>The little moments I have struck thy wire—</br>For oft to banish woe, with thee I've sat,</br>And milder thoughts thy tones did aye inspire;—</br>Tho' not at all times when I might desire,</br>Thy sounds, tho' weak at best, would deign to swell—</br>And oft I've blam'd thee for a cruel lyre,</br>That could to woe refuse thy lulling spell.—</br>Now let us part as friends — poor, feeble harp, farewell!—</br>
